qa.q: What are the symptoms?
qa.a: Symptoms of COVID-19 include coughing and shortness of breath. Additionally, a person showing two or more of the following symptoms may have the virus: fever, repeated shaking with chills, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, new loss of taste or smell.

qa.q: Who is most at risk?
qa.a: Anyone can catch and become seriously ill with COVID-19, but people who are older or immunocompromised, or who have pre-existing conditions including hypertension, diabetes or chronic lung disease (such as asthma) are at heightened risk.

qa.q: What is a pandemic?
qa.a: An outbreak of a disease that occurs over a wide geographic area and affects an exceptionally high proportion of the population.

qa.q: What is a coronavirus?
qa.a: COVID-19 is caused by a coronavirus. Coronaviruses are a family of common viruses affecting people and many species of animal, including camels, cattle, cats, and bats. Very rarely, animal coronaviruses transfer to people and then spread, as with MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and now SARS-CoV-2, the virus train that causes COVID-19. About a third of common colds in humans are caused by coronaviruses.

qa.q: How does COVID-19 spread?
qa.a: The disease spreads primarily from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth, which are expelled when a person with COVID-19 coughs, sneezes, or speak. People can catch COVID-19 if they breathe in these droplets. These droplets can land on objects and surfaces around the person such as tables, doorknobs and handrails. People can become infected by touching these, then touching their eyes, nose or mouth.

qa.q: Who can I talk to for advice?
qa.a: Anyone with a primary care physician should contact them with concerns about COVID-19. Alternatively, a free statewide hotline is available between 8am and 5pm, seven days a week, on (833) 544-2374. This can offer advice on everything from preventing the virus' spread, to getting help if you don’t have health insurance, to local services like food delivery and mental health care.

qa.q: Should I wear a mask or facial covering?
qa.a: As of April 22, six of nine Bay Area counties (Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, San Mateo and Sonoma) now require people to wear masks or facial coverings when outside of their homes. Business have the right to refuse service to anybody not wearing a mask and many public tranist agencies have adopted similar stances. Masks are not necessary when driving your personal vehicle or while excercising, provided you keep 6 feet of distance between yourself and anybody not from your household.

qa.q: Is BART running through the COVID-19 emergency period?
qa.a: BART operates Monday through Friday from 5am - 9pm, with the same train frequency as before the emergency. Weekend trains now run from 8am - 9pm instead of 6am - midnight, but also with the same frequency as before. SFO is currently offering a late-night shuttle service to and from several BART stations. qa.q: How can I help high risk individuals in my neighborhood?
qa.a: The CDC considers the elderly and people with chronic illnesses to be at higher risk from COVID-19. If you're in a lower risk group, you can help your neighbors and foster community by offering to pick up prescriptions and groceries for them and while following safe handling precautions.  Social visits from a safe distance can help brighten people's moods and provide an opportunity to share information and stay in touch.

qa.q: Where can I talk to someone to get support when self isolating?
qa.a: San Francisco Mental Health Warm Line which has statwide coverage at (855) 845-7415 as well as the option to chat online.

qa.q: How can I reach out for help if I'm quarantined with an abuser?
qa.a: Women Organized to Make Abuse Nonexistent, Inc. (W.O.M.A.N., Inc.) is a community-based, multi-service agency, serving survivors of domestic violence in San Francisco and the larger Bay Area. If you need help or need someone to talk to they have a 24/7 hotline at (415) 864-4722 or (877) 384-3578.

qa.q: If I'm having thoughts of harming myself during self-quarantine, where can I go for help?
qa.a: San Francisco Suicide Prevention’s 24-hour Crisis Line provides immediate crisis intervention and emotional support to everyone who calls. Call (415) 781-0500 or text MYLIFE to 741741.

qa.q: Where can I go to access AA meetings and/or access substance abuse resources?
qa.a: Call the Alcoholics Anonymous helpline at (415) 674-1821 or email them at help@aasfmarin.org. To reach Narcotics Anonymous, call (415) 610-7294. Online meetings are also available at https://www.aa-intergroup.org/ https://www.weconnectrecovery.com and www.intherooms.com.

qa.q: What is Social Distancing?
qa.a: Social distancing means deliberately increasing the physical space between people to avoid spreading illness.

qa.q: What activities are allowed/restricted under shelter in place guidelines?
qa.a: Stay home and avoid non-essential travel. If you must go out, maintain 6ft separation from people you do not live with. Conduct work and/or school from home if possible. Visit with friends and loved ones via phone or video call rather than in person.

qa.q: What is shelter in place? How long will it be for?
qa.a: Since March 19 Californians have been sheltering in place. Individuals have been instructed to stay home unless they are getting food, caring for relatives, seeking urgent medical care or working in essential services. On May 4, however, Governor Gavin Newsom announced a relaxing of the state-wide shelter in place order and restrictions on business, based on improving data about the virus' spread. Broadly, from Friday May 8, non-essential businesses will be able to re-open for curbside service. Individual counties will have latitude to act on this as they see fit so long as certain safeguards are in place. Watch this space.

qa.q: What does self quarantine and isolation mean? How do I self quarantine?
qa.a: Isolation and quarantine help protect the public by preventing exposure to people who have or may have a contagious disease. Isolation separates sick people with a contagious disease from people who are not sick. Quarantine restricts the movement of people who were or might have been exposed to a contagious disease, to see if they become sick or not. For COVID-19 the standard quarantine period is 14 days.

qa.q: What do I do if a family member has to quarantine?
